Title: Conjecture: If $n$ is an odd positive integer then $\gcd\left(2^{n}+5,5^{n}-3^{n}\right)=1$.
Content:
I've tried to prove that $2^{n}+5$ will not divide $5^{n}-3^{n}$ using Jacobi symbol , but this is still not sufficient to prove that $\gcd\left(2^{n}+5,5^{n}-3^{n}\right)=1$ . The proof of $2^{n}+5$ will not divide $5^{n}-3^{n}$ : Assuming that $2^{n}+5$ will divide $5^{n}-3^{n}$ : If n is even As $\operatorname{ord}_3(2) = 2$ , so $2^{2k} \equiv 1 \pmod{3}$ and $5 \equiv -1 \pmod{3}$ Thus $ 2^{2k} +5 \equiv 0 \pmod{3}$ , so $3$ $\mid$ $2^{n}+5$ $\Rightarrow$ $ 3 \mid 5^{n}-3^{n}$ , which is a contradiction ! $\Rightarrow$ n is odd How ever , $2^{n}+5$ will divide $5^{n}-3^{n} \Rightarrow 5^n \equiv 3^n \pmod{2^{n}+5}$ $\Rightarrow \displaystyle \left( \frac{5^n}{2^{n}+5} \right)$ $=$ $\displaystyle \left( \frac{3^n}{2^{n}+5} \right)$ $\Rightarrow \displaystyle \left( \frac{5}{2^{n}+5} \right)^n =  \displaystyle \left( \frac{3}{2^{n}+5} \right) ^n$ Since n is odd $\Rightarrow \displaystyle \left( \frac{5}{2^{n}+5} \right) =  \displaystyle \left( \frac{3}{2^{n}+5} \right)$ Now using the extended law of quadratic reciprocity with the Jacobi symbol , if a and b are odd positive coprime integers then : $
\displaystyle \left( \frac{a}{b} \right) = (-1)^{\frac{(a-1)(b-1)}{4}}$ $\displaystyle \left( \frac{b}{a} \right)$ In our case $5$ and $2^n + 5$ are odd positive coprime integers , also for $3$ and $2^n +5$ . Thus $\displaystyle \left( \frac{5}{2^{n}+5} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{5} \right) \times (-1)^{\frac{5-1}{2} \times \frac{2^{n}+5-1}{2}} = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{5} \right)$ because $\frac{5-1}{2} =2$ $\Rightarrow \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{5} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}}{5} \right)$ because $\text{if } a \equiv b \pmod{c}, \text{ then } \displaystyle \left( \frac{a}{c} \right) = \left( \frac{b}{c} \right)$ $\Rightarrow  \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}}{5} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2}{5} \right)^n = (-1)^{\frac{5^2-1}{8}} = (-1)^3 = -1$ In the other hand , using the extended law of quadratic reciprocity, we have : $\displaystyle \left( \frac{3}{2^{n}+5} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{3} \right) \times (-1)^{\frac{3-1}{2} \times \frac{2^{n}+5-1}{2}} = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{3} \right) \times (-1)^{\frac{2^{n}+4}{2}}$ $= \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{3} \right) \times (-1)^{2^{n-1}+2} = \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{3} \right)$ , because $n > 1$ $\Rightarrow \displaystyle \left( \frac{2^{n}+5}{3} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{(-1)^{n}-1}{3} \right) $ , since $5 \equiv -1 \pmod{3}$ and $2 \equiv -1 \pmod{3}$ As n is odd, then $\displaystyle \left( \frac{(-1)^{n}-1}{3} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{-2}{3} \right) = \displaystyle \left( \frac{1}{3} \right) = 1$ Thus $\displaystyle \left( \frac{5^n}{2^{n}+5} \right)$ $=$ $\displaystyle \left( \frac{3^n}{2^{n}+5} \right) = 1 =-1$ which is a contradiction ! Conclusion , $2^{n}+5$ will not divide $5^{n}-3^{n}$ but why $\gcd\left(2^{n}+5,5^{n}-3^{n}\right)=1$ ? Thanks for help !
AcceptedAnswer: Let $n_0$ be an odd integer such that $n_0 \geq 3$ . Since $\gcd(5, 3) = 1$ , by Zsigmondy’s theorem, $5^{n_0} - 3^{n_0}$ has a primitive prime divisor $p$ . In particular, $p$ is odd (since $p$ does not divide $5 - 3$ ) moreover $p \neq 3$ , so $3$ has an inverse modulo $p$ . In the cyclic group $(F_p^*, \times)$ where $F_p = \mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ , we have $\frac{5}{3}$ of order $n_0$ : $O\left(\frac{5}{3}\right) = n_0$ . Thus, $p \mid 5^n - 3^n$ if and only if $n_0 \mid n$ . To find $n$ such that $\gcd(5^n - 3^n, 2^n + 5) > 1$ , it suffices that $n = (2k + 1)n_0$ and $p \mid 2^n + 5$ . In $(F_p^{*},\times)$ : $$2^{(2k+1)n_0} + 5 = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad (4^{n_0})^k = -\frac{5}{2^{n_0}} ,$$ where $2^{n_0}$ is invertible modulo $p$ (since $p$ is odd). Thus, we have $-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}} \in \text{gr}(4^{n_0})$ , where $\text{gr}(4^{n_0})$ denotes the subgroup of $(F_p)^*$ generated by $4^{n_0}$ . We recall that , in a cyclic group, $x \in \text{gr}(a)$ if and only if $o(x)$ divides $o(a)$ . Thus, $$-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}} \in \text{gr}(4^{n_0}) \quad \Leftrightarrow \quad o\left(-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}}\right) \mid o(4^{n_0}).$$ Conclusion: To find the existence of an odd $n$ such that $\gcd(5^n - 3^n, 2^n + 5) > 1$ , follow these steps: Start with $n_0 = 3$ . If a primitive divisor $p$ of $5^{n_0} - 3^{n_0}$ is found such that $o\left(-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}}\right)$ divides $o(4^{n_0})$ , then we are done. Otherwise, replace $n_0$ by $n_0 + 2$ and repeat the process. For $n_0 = 25$ , we verify the factorization of $5^{n_0} - 3^{n_0}$ as: $$5^{n_0} - 3^{n_0} = 131 \times 2 \times 11 \times p,$$ where $p = 103408180634401$ . Since $5^5 - 3^5 = 2 \times 11 \times 131$ , $p$ is a primitive prime divisor of $5^{n_0} - 3^{n_0}$ and $o\left(\frac{5}{3}\right) = 25$ in $(F_p^*, \times)$ . Additionally, we have $o\left(-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}}\right) = 43086741931$ , and $o(4^{n_0}) = 517040903172 = 12 \times o\left(-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}}\right)$ . Thus, there exists a $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $-\frac{5}{2^{n_0}} = (4^{n_0})^k$ , and hence $n = n_0(2k + 1)$ answers the question. Remark , there is infinitely odd numbers n such that $\gcd(5^n-3^n,2^n+5) \neq 1$ In fact, it suffices to replace $k$ by $k'=k+m\times(p-1)$
